acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of >10,000mg/kg (IUCLID (2000)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category R by NTP (2005), Group 2B by IARC (1987), Category A3 by ACGIH (2001) and Category 2B by Japan Society for Occupational Health.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale:
No data available
As for the health hazards, refer to "ID168, Lead, CAS: 7439-92-1," "ID48, Lead Oxide (II); Litharge, CAS: 1317-36-8" and "ID47, Lead Acetate (II), CAS: 301-04-2."

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though inorganic compounds containing oxygen

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: May damage fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale:
Based on expert judgment, given the fact that lead has been known to possess developmental neurotoxic and reproductive toxic potentials in humans.
As for the health hazards, refer to "ID168, Lead, CAS: 7439-92-1," "ID48, Lead Oxide (II); Litharge, CAS: 1317-36-8" and "ID47, Lead Acetate (II), CAS: 301-04-2."

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (blood system, kidney, nervous system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale:
Based on toxicity of inorganic lead compounds.  

Based on the human evidence: "The effects observed in acute and chronic studies are very similar for inorganic lead compounds. Inhalation or oral ingestion of inorganic lead has been reported to induce oral contraction and thirst, along with nausea, vomiting, upper abdominal discomfort, loss of appetite, abdominal pain and constipation suggesting gastrointestinal toxicity. The effects on hematopoietic function such as hemoglobin synthesis inhibition due to delta-aminolevulinic acid/heme synthetic enzyme inhibition and anemia caused by shortened survival of red blood cells are considered representative of toxic actions of inorganic lead. Kidney effects are evidenced by interstitial nephropathy and decreased urinary output along with proximal renal tubular damage showing Fanconi's syndrome represented by proteinuria, hematuria, urinary cast, glycosuria and aminoaciduria. Inorganic lead adversely affects the central and peripheral nervous systems, displaying in particular weakening of the muscle of the limbs, pain and spasm. 
There have been rare reports of adults exhibiting ataxia, headache, paresthesia, depression and coma indicative of toxic effects on the central nervous system when exposing to extremely high doses (details not shown). However, children are most sensitive to toxicity of lead, and neurodevelopmental toxicity manifested as restlessness, aggression, concentration difficulties and memory lapse has become serious problem in the U.S." (CERI Hazard Data 2001-9 (2002)).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (blood system, kidney, nervous system)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale:
Based on toxicity of inorganic lead compounds.  

Based on the human evidence: "The effects observed in acute and chronic studies are very similar for inorganic lead compounds. Inhalation or oral ingestion of inorganic lead has been reported to induce oral contraction and thirst, along with nausea, vomiting, upper abdominal discomfort, loss of appetite, abdominal pain and constipation suggesting gastrointestinal toxicity. The effects on hematopoietic function such as hemoglobin synthesis inhibition due to delta-aminolevulinic acid/heme synthetic enzyme inhibition and anemia caused by shortened survival of red blood cells are considered representative of toxic actions of inorganic lead. Kidney effects are evidenced by interstitial nephropathy and decreased urinary output along with proximal renal tubular damage showing Fanconi's syndrome represented by proteinuria, hematuria, urinary cast, glycosuria and aminoaciduria. Inorganic lead adversely affects the central and peripheral nervous systems, displaying in particular weakening of the muscle of the limbs, pain and spasm. 
There have been rare reports of adults exhibiting ataxia, headache, paresthesia, depression and coma indicative of toxic effects on the central nervous system when exposing to extremely high doses (details not shown). However, children are most sensitive to toxicity of lead, and neurodevelopmental toxicity manifested as restlessness, aggression, concentration difficulties and memory lapse has become serious problem in the U.S." (CERI Hazard Data 2001-9 (2002)).
